_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Note to explain Fire walls-These are at the deluge manifold for personnel protection when accessing this area.
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Benzene Monitors, Vibration alarms on pumps, and leak detection and repair monitoring for VOC

_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Deluge system on MVRU and fixed water monitors
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Process area H2S monitors; benzene fence line monitors that are checked every two weeks

_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Water cannons located at each corner of D-9520/21 to provide deluge
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: 12 NH3 detectors in 95 Plant and NH3 detection cameras on the storage vessels

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Chevron Pascagoula Refinery Risk Management Plan
Executive Summary 
October 2024

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES  

Our Operational Excellence (OE) Vision is to protect our workforce, community, environment, and assets by operating without fatalities or high consequence incidents.

At the Chevron Pascagoula Refinery, protecting people and the environment is a core value.  In accordance with the values and beliefs outlined in the Chevron Way; the refinery, employees, and contractors strive to always:
	Eliminate fatalities, serious injuries, and illnesses
	Eliminate high-consequence process safety incidents and operate with industry-leading reliability
	Identify and confirm appropriate safeguards are in place and functioning
	Assess and manage environmental risks
	Use energy and resources efficiently
	Prevent high-consequence security and cybersecurity incidents
	Address OE business risks through stakeholder engagement and issues management

Additionally, the Chevron Pascagoula Refinery has well-established policies and procedures for each of the 14 elements of Process Safety Management (PSM).

DESCRIPTION OF SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The Chevron Pascagoula Refinery, located in a rural area in southeastern Mississippi, receives crude oil by tanker and pipeline for processing into various products through refining techniques such as distillation, hydrotreating, hydrocracking, alkylation, hydrogen production, sulfur recovery, etc.  

Regulated flammable substances are present at the refinery as flammable mixtures. Primary components of the mixtures are propane, butane, pentane and propylene. Secondary components of the mixtures include chemicals such as hydrogen, methane, ethane, ethylene, butene, isobutane, isobutene, 2-butene-cis, 2-butene-trans, 1,3-butadiene, 2-pentene (E) 2-pentene(Z), and isopentane. The only RMP regulated toxic substance that the refinery has above threshold quantities at a concentration higher than 1% b

y weight is anhydrous ammonia.

Using EPA's RMP Guidance, Chevron reevaluated each worst-case scenario to only include the greatest amount in a single vessel, which affected the results of each scenario compared to previous evaluations. There were no major changes to the existing processes themselves. 

Additionally, a previously decommissioned plant has been retrofitted into a Naphtha Distillation Unit, which is set to be commissioned by the end of 2024. This will be a Program Level 1 process (Process ID 1000147396) containing a flammable mixture and has been included in Section 1.17 and Section 4.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM STEPS

The Chevron Pascagoula Refinery complies with OSHA standards for PSM (1910.119) and Emergency Response Management (1910.120). The site maintains a Stormwater Pollution Prevention Plan, Spill Prevention Control Countermeasure Plan, and Waste Minimization Plan to comply with various state and federal environmental regulations. Additionally, policies and procedures are in place to meet Title V, RCRA, and HSWA permit requirements.

Chevron has individual programs for each of the 14 elements of PSM. These programs are managed through our OE Risk Management system to ensure that potential hazards are evaluated, safeguards are appropriately identified and maintained, and all stakeholders are adequately trained on hazards.

Periodic first-, second-, and third-party audits are conducted to ensure compliance with these programs. 

CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The Refinery has safety features within the process units that are designed to quickly prevent, contain, control, and/or reduce the consequence(s) of a release.  The following is a list of preventative and mitigative safeguards in place.

Preventative Safeguards:
	Low/High Process Alarms (i.e. temperature, pressure, level)
	Safety Instrumented Systems (SIS) 
	Pressure relief devices
	Process controls and interlocks
	Redundant equipment and instrumentation (cont

inuous power supply for control systems, backup pumps, atmospheric relief devices, etc.)

Mitigative Safeguards:
	Diked or berms to contain liquid releases
	Fire suppression, deluge, and extinguishing systems
	Inerting/purging systems
	Emergency Response Team (ERT)
	Spill containment equipment (i.e. absorbent pads and booms)
	Process/perimeter monitoring/detection alarms
	Personal protective equipment
	Internal and external communication systems
Other safeguards may be in-place but not included in the lists above.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Chevron Pascagoula Refinery has had one RMP reportable accident within the past 5 years, an accidental release of approximately 181 pounds of NH3 and 99 pounds of H2S in May 2024. While this incident did not have impact outside of the refinery, it was considered in this report due to the precautionary sheltering in place of Mississippi Power, an on-site, third-party power generation facility. A meeting was held with Mississippi Power, which was the only offsite entity that experienced a consequence from the release. The information required by 40 CFR 68.42(b) was provided to Mississippi Power.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION
 
The refinery maintains a written emergency response plan that details activation of the Incident Command System in the event of a release of a regulated substance, fire, explosion, or medical event. This plan specifies instructions on responding to an emergency, required training, notification of affected parties, incident review, etc. Chevrons stand-alone ERT is the primary responding entity to any RMP-related release/accident with local first responders as supplemental support if needed. The ERT is equipped with the following resources to respond to onsite events:
	Aerial platform truck 
	Three foam pumper trucks
	High-angle rescue truck
	Medical transport vehicle
	Portable firewater pumps/nozzles

ERT members participate in onsite training monthly and routinely attend offsite

training for skills such as Hazmat response, foam application, rescue skills, etc. Hypothetical and formal drills are also conducted on a regular basis. Formal drills include offsite response teams such as local fire department, ambulance services, hospital, and Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) members.

The overall emergency response program for the Chevron Refinery is coordinated with the Jackson County LEPC.  This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee, which has members from the local emergency response community, local government officials, and industry representatives. The refinery has the capability for around-the-clock communications with appropriate LEPC officials. This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Personal and process safety are integral to refinery operations, and continuous efforts are made to identify and implement safety improvements. Examples of recent/proposed safety improvements to the facility are listed below:
	Quantitative Risk Screening (QRS) adopted for consequence severity estimation for Process Hazard Analyses (PHA), Layers of Protection Analysis (LOPA), and facility siting assessments
	Cross-functional PSM project team in place to manage open risk gaps including relief concern mitigations and PHA recommendations
	Updated emergency horn system with distinct tones for fire, toxic release, and all clear 
	Continued efforts to upgrade metallurgy in high consequence service through Alloy-Up Investment Program
	Implementing/updating Independent Protection Layer (IPL) Management program
	Future relocation of fire response team/equipment to allow for improved response capabilities
